items.title: Japan's 40-year bond suffers historic selloff amid fears over tax cut plan

featured_image.name: JAPAN-POLITICS-ELECTION

items.description:
Japanese government bonds experienced a historic meltdown on Tuesday as fiscal concerns over Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi's unfunded tax cut promises sent long-dated yields surging to levels not seen in decades, triggering a selloff that spread across global financial markets.

The yield on Japan's 40-year government bond rocketed past 4%, the highest since this maturity was introduced in 2007 and a first for any sovereign debt instrument in the country in more than three decades. The 30-year yield climbed to a record 3.875%, while the benchmark 10-year yield rose above 2.3%, its highest level since 1999.[1][2][3]

items.title: Hubble images show interstellar object's jets in rare symmetry

featured_image.name: Three perfect mini-jets, one chilling question: Is 3I/ATLAS engineered?

items.description:
New images of the interstellar visitor 3I/ATLAS from the Hubble Space Telescope have revealed an unusual configuration of jets emanating from its nucleus, with three distinct plumes arranged in near-perfect 120-degree symmetry. Harvard astrophysicist Avi Loeb, who has been analyzing the data, says the geometric precision of the formation is difficult to reconcile with standard cometary outgassing and raises questions about the object's origins.

Images captured by Hubble on January 7 and January 14, 2026, and processed by researcher Toni Scarmato using the Larson-Sekanina Rotational Gradient filter, show three collimated mini-jets extending tens of thousands of kilometers into space, each separated by exactly 120 degrees in projection. A fourth "anti-tail" jet points directly toward the sun, stretching up to 400,000 kilometers — a length that Loeb argues has never been reported before for solar system comets.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Chinese researchers achieve 31% efficiency in perovskite solar cells

featured_image.name: Chinese scientists boost perovskite solar cell efficiency ...

items.description:
Scientists in China and Hong Kong have announced separate advances in perovskite solar cell technology this month, addressing long-standing challenges with both efficiency and stability that have hindered the material's commercial adoption.

A research team from Northwestern Polytechnical University, in collaboration with Xi'an Shiyou University and Xidian University, developed a novel crystallization strategy using a two-dimensional seeding agent to achieve 31.13% efficiency in a perovskite-silicon tandem solar cell. Separately, engineers at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology created a "Molecular Velcro" coating that enables cells to retain over 95% of their initial efficiency after more than 1,100 hours of continuous operation under intense heat.[1][2][3][4][5]

items.title: Asian and European stocks fall as Trump tariff threats roil markets

featured_image.name: European stocks slide as Trump's Greenland tariff threat rattles investors

items.description:
Stock markets across Asia and Europe tumbled Tuesday as investors grappled with escalating trade tensions after President Donald Trump threatened tariffs on eight European nations in his bid to acquire Greenland, while Japan's snap election announcement failed to lift regional sentiment.

The pan-European STOXX 600 fell 0.8% on Tuesday, extending its worst session in over two months, while the STOXX 50 declined 0.4%. In Asia, Japan's Nikkei 225 dropped approximately 0.8%, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng and China's Shanghai Composite shed 0.1% to 0.5%.[1][2][3][4][5]

items.title: Trump arrives at Davos amid EU standoff over Greenland tariffs

featured_image.name: Trump will attend Davos forum in 2026, White House official says

items.description:
President Donald Trump is set to take center stage at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday, where trade tensions with European allies over his renewed push to acquire Greenland threaten to dominate proceedings at the elite annual gathering.

The 56th World Economic Forum, running January 19-23, has been overshadowed by Trump's weekend announcement of new tariffs targeting eight European nations — Germany, France, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, Finland, Sweden, Norway, and Denmark — unless a deal is reached allowing the United States to purchase Greenland, the mineral-rich Danish territory in the Arctic.[1][2]

items.title: World Economic Forum opens without founder Schwab for first time

featured_image.name: SWITZERLAND-POLITICS-SUMMIT-DIPLOMACY-WEF

items.description:
The 56th World Economic Forum Annual Meeting commenced in Davos on Monday evening, marking the first time in the event's history that founder Klaus Schwab was not at the helm. Interim co-chairs Larry Fink and André Hoffmann opened proceedings with welcoming remarks at an opening concert, signaling a new chapter for the influential gathering of global elites.

Schwab, 87, stepped down as chairman in April 2025, effective immediately, after the WEF board moved to investigate whistleblower allegations of financial and ethical misconduct involving him and his wife, Hilde. The Wall Street Journal first reported that an anonymous letter to the board accused the Schwabs of improperly intermingling personal finances with forum resources, including allegations that Schwab directed subordinates to withdraw thousands of dollars from ATMs on his behalf and used WEF funds for private hotel massages.[1][2][3]

items.title: Antarctic penguins breeding weeks earlier in fastest shift ever recorded

featured_image.name: As climate change melts Antarctic ice, gentoo penguins ...

items.description:
Antarctic penguins are advancing their breeding seasons at record rates as their habitats warm up to four times faster than the continental average, according to research released on World Penguin Awareness Day that identifies the fastest such shift ever recorded in any bird — and possibly any vertebrate.

The decade-long study, published Tuesday in the Journal of Animal Ecology, found that three penguin species on the Antarctic Peninsula are now beginning their reproductive cycles approximately two weeks earlier than they did a decade ago, with some colonies shifting by nearly a month.[1][2][3]

items.title: Experts warn Iran's nuclear stockpile at risk amid unrest

featured_image.name: Report: Iran increased stockpile of uranium enriched to near ...

items.description:
As the United States and Iran trade escalating threats amid Tehran's bloody crackdown on protesters, nuclear experts are sounding alarms about the potential for Iran's nuclear materials to fall into the wrong hands during a period of internal chaos.

The warning, detailed in a report by the Associated Press, comes as the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) has acknowledged losing visibility over Iran's stockpile of highly enriched uranium following U.S. and Israeli airstrikes on nuclear facilities last June.[1][2]

items.title: 1,500 ISIS prisoners escape Syrian facility as ceasefire collapses

featured_image.name: ISIL fighters flee jail as Syrian army clashes with Kurdish-led SDF

items.description:
Approximately 1,500 Islamic State members escaped from Shaddadi prison in northeastern Syria on Monday, according to the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces, as a ceasefire deal between Kurdish fighters and the Damascus government appeared to collapse just one day after it was announced.

SDF spokesperson Farhad Shami told the Kurdish website Rudaw that the mass prison break occurred after "Damascus factions" launched repeated attacks on the facility, which held thousands of ISIS detainees. The Syrian army denied attacking the prison and instead accused the SDF of deliberately releasing the militants. By Monday evening, Syrian officials said they had regained control of both the city and the prison, and imposed a curfew while troops searched for escapees.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Scientists predict 2026 will extend streak of record global heat

featured_image.name: This year is expected to rival some of the hottest ever recorded ...

items.description:
The World Meteorological Organization confirmed this week that 2025 was among the three warmest years on record, while Canadian and European climate scientists predict 2026 will extend an unprecedented streak of extreme global heat that shows no signs of abating.

The global average surface temperature in 2025 reached 1.44°C above pre-industrial levels, according to the WMO's consolidated analysis of eight international datasets, placing it effectively tied with 2023 and trailing only 2024, which remains the hottest year on record at 1.55°C above the 1850-1900 baseline.[1][2][3]

items.title: Trump, China's He Lifeng court CEOs at Davos amid trade tensions

featured_image.name: Trump to meet global CEOs in Davos, with US policy in ...

items.description:
As more than 850 chief executives gather in the Swiss Alps for the World Economic Forum, both the United States and China are competing for their attention, with President Donald Trump and Chinese Vice Premier He Lifeng scheduling separate meetings with global business leaders amid renewed trade talks and escalating geopolitical tensions.

Trump plans to convene a group of corporate executives Wednesday evening following his anticipated speech at the forum, according to Semafor and Reuters. The invitations, sent from the White House, caught some executives off guard Monday, forcing corporate staffers to scramble to rework schedules that had been months in the making.[1][2]

items.title: Greenland dispute could suck oxygen from Davos talks, Stubb says

featured_image.name: Finnish President Alexander Stubb speaks at the Annual ...

items.description:
Finnish President Alexander Stubb voiced concerns on Monday that escalating tensions over Greenland will "suck out all the oxygen" at this week's World Economic Forum in Davos, potentially sidelining critical discussions about ending Russia's war in Ukraine and securing the country's reconstruction.[1]

"We are doing everything we can to avoid that," Stubb told reporters in Davos on Monday, adding that "for Ukraine, the best that can come out of Davos is some kind of an agreement on an economic plan or reconstruction".[1]

The warning comes as the 56th World Economic Forum opened January 19 under the theme "A Spirit of Dialogue," with nearly 3,000 participants from more than 130 countries, including approximately 65 heads of state and six G7 leaders. Yet the gathering has been upended by President Donald Trump's threat to impose escalating tariffs on European allies unless they acquiesce to American acquisition of Greenland.[2][3]

items.title: Denmark, Greenland propose NATO Arctic surveillance mission

featured_image.name: TOPSHOT-GREENLAND-DENMARK-US-DEFENCE-NATO

items.description:
Denmark and Greenland have formally proposed establishing a NATO surveillance mission in the Arctic, Danish Defence Minister Troels Lund Poulsen announced Monday after meeting with NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte in Brussels. The proposal marks an attempt to address escalating transatlantic tensions sparked by U.S. President Donald Trump's push to acquire the strategically located island.

"We have proposed it, the secretary general has taken note of that, and I think we can now—we hope—define a framework on how that can be concretised," Poulsen told Danish television following the meeting, which also included Greenlandic Foreign Minister Vivian Motzfeldt.[1][2][3]

items.title: Denmark deploys combat troops to Greenland amid Trump threats

featured_image.name: TOPSHOT-GREENLAND-DENMARK-US-DEFENCE-NATO

items.description:
Denmark is deploying a substantial contingent of combat soldiers to Greenland on Monday evening, with Army Chief Major General Peter Boysen accompanying the forces as Copenhagen reinforces its Arctic presence in the face of escalating pressure from U.S. President Donald Trump to acquire the self-governing territory.

The Danish Armed Forces confirmed to broadcaster TV 2 that the additional troops are scheduled to arrive in Kangerlussuaq, describing the deployment as "a substantial contribution." Around 100 Danish soldiers had already arrived in Nuuk, Greenland's capital, with a similar number stationed in Kangerlussuaq before the latest reinforcement.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Trump to meet with global CEOs after Davos keynote address

featured_image.name: Trump to meet global CEOs in Davos, with US policy in spotlight

items.description:
Business executives attending this week's World Economic Forum received an unexpected invitation on Monday: President Donald Trump wants to meet with them after his Wednesday keynote address in Davos, Switzerland.

The U.S. president plans to convene a group of corporate executives following his speech at the forum, according to Reuters and Semafor, though the agenda remains unclear. The invitations, which originated from the White House, sent corporate staffers scrambling to rework schedules that had been months in the making.[1][2]

items.title: German Chancellor Merz seeks Trump meeting at Davos over Greenland

featured_image.name: Merz to Meet Trump in Davos to Avoid Escalation in Trade ...

items.description:
German Chancellor Friedrich Merz announced Monday he will attempt to meet with President Donald Trump at the World Economic Forum in Davos this week to defuse escalating tensions over Greenland, as Europe prepares potential countermeasures against threatened U.S. tariffs.

Speaking at a press conference in Berlin, Merz said European nations that expressed solidarity with Denmark want to prevent the dispute from spiraling further. "We will have the opportunity this week in Davos to discuss this in various meetings. I will try to meet with President Trump on Wednesday," Merz said. Trump is scheduled to deliver a special address at the forum on January 21.[1][2]

items.title: Italian PM Meloni offers to mediate US-Europe standoff over Greenland

featured_image.name: Italy's Meloni Offers to Be Europe's Mediator With Trump on ...

items.description:
Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni positioned herself as a potential bridge between Washington and European capitals on Sunday, calling President Donald Trump's tariff threats over Greenland "a mistake" while suggesting the crisis stemmed from a "communication breakdown" rather than fundamental disagreement among allies.

Speaking during a visit to Seoul on January 18, Meloni disclosed that she had spoken directly with Trump "a few hours ago" and conveyed her concerns about the escalating tensions. "There has been a problem of understanding and communication," she told reporters, arguing that European military deployments to Greenland were misinterpreted as anti-American when they were actually intended to deter "other actors" — a reference to Russia and China.[1][2]

items.title: France rejects Trump's Gaza Board of Peace, citing UN concerns

featured_image.name: 80th session of the United Nations General Assembly in ...

items.description: France will not accept an invitation to join President Donald Trump's "Board of Peace" initiative aimed at overseeing Gaza's governance, according to a source close to President Emmanuel Macron. The announcement comes as the French government simultaneously pursues its own path of engagement in the region, dispatching nearly 400 tons of humanitarian aid to the war-ravaged territory.[1][2]

items.title: Prince Harry's privacy trial against Daily Mail begins in London

featured_image.name: Prince Harry Appears in Court for Daily Mail Publisher ...

items.description:
Prince Harry arrived at London's High Court on Monday, waving to reporters and saying "good morning" as he entered via a side entrance for the start of what his legal team calls the "final chapter" of his crusade against British tabloid media. The Duke of Sussex, 41, sat in the back row of the courtroom alongside actresses Elizabeth Hurley and Sadie Frost as his barrister, David Sherborne, alleged the Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday engaged in "clear, systematic and sustained use of unlawful information gathering" spanning two decades.[1][2]

The civil trial, expected to last nine weeks, sees Harry and six other high-profile claimants accusing Associated Newspapers Limited of illegal practices including phone hacking, hiring private investigators to plant listening devices in homes and cars, and obtaining medical and financial records through deception—a practice known as "blagging". The publisher has "vigorously denied" all allegations, calling them "preposterous smears" and part of a "coordinated effort" against the media.[3][4][5]

items.title: Japan's PM Takaichi calls snap election for February 8

featured_image.name: Japan's Leader Calls for Snap Election in Bid to Expand Power

items.description:
Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi announced Monday that she will dissolve parliament on Friday and hold a snap general election on February 8, just three months after becoming the country's first female leader. The move sets the stage for a high-stakes campaign as Takaichi seeks a stronger mandate to advance her fiscal policies and hardline security stance amid escalating tensions with China.

"I want the public to decide whether Sanae Takaichi is suitable as prime minister," she told reporters at a press conference in Tokyo. Official campaigning will begin on January 27, with only 16 days between the dissolution and voting day, the shortest such period since the end of World War II.[1][2]
